title: 103_hr3814
content: The "Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994" includes reforms to monthly insurance benefits for disabilities involving substance abuse. Amendments to the Social Security Act include rules for suspending benefits and continued payments during rehabilitation programs. Nonpayment of benefits due to substance abuse is also addressed. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 addresses the suspension of disability benefits for individuals determined to be drug addicts or alcoholics. Benefits can be reinstated after undergoing a 3-month treatment program and showing progress towards recovery. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 suspends disability benefits for individuals deemed drug addicts or alcoholics. Benefits can be reinstated after a 3-month treatment program and progress towards recovery. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 suspends disability benefits for individuals who do not recover from their condition after a 3-month treatment program. If the person fails to continue treatment, benefits will not be paid until completing 2 weeks of treatment. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 suspends disability benefits for individuals who fail to continue treatment as required. No benefit based on disability shall be paid until completing 2 months of treatment. The Disability Insurance Reform Act of 1994 suspends disability benefits for individuals who fail to continue treatment as required. Monthly insurance benefits under this title for disabled individuals are payable as if they were receiving benefits not payable under certain conditions. The Secretary is responsible for monitoring and testing individuals receiving benefits who must undergo treatment. The Secretary is responsible for monitoring individuals receiving disability benefits to ensure compliance with treatment requirements. The Secretary may retain jurisdiction for hearings as necessary and must submit an annual report to Congress on activities. Standards for drug and alcohol treatment programs will be developed in consultation with professionals, and guidelines for reviewing participant progress will be established in collaboration with states. The amendments made by this section will preserve Medicare benefits for individuals not eligible due to certain reasons, treating them as entitled to benefits. These changes will apply to benefits payable 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Restriction of future representative payees to government agencies, state-licensed facilities, or state-bonded community-based nonprofit social service agencies. Restriction to Qualified Organizations under Section 205(j) of the Social Security Act includes amending paragraphs to specify qualified organizations as representative payees. This involves changes such as replacing references to "person" with "qualified organization" and updating identification numbers accordingly. The amendment involves specifying qualified organizations as representative payees by replacing references to "person" with "qualified organization" and updating identification numbers accordingly. The term 'qualified organization' in this subsection refers to specific entities like state agencies, nonprofit care facilities, and bonded social service agencies. Amendments are made to specify qualified organizations as representative payees. Amendments are made to section 205(j)(4) of the Act, allowing qualified organizations to collect monthly fees from individuals for services provided. The changes include redefining terms like "individual" to "person" and specifying qualified organizations as representative payees. Amendments to section 205(j)(4) of the Act allow organizations to act as representative payees for individuals, with fees capped at 10% of the monthly benefit. Any agreement exceeding this amount is void. The changes also redefine terms and are effective for payments made after the enactment of this Act. Section 205(j) of the Social Security Act will continue to apply to representative payees until their certification ceases to be effective.
